metadata.notes: Batch 2 audit: Betsy Amster through Corey Van Landingham

writers.name: Betsy Amster
writers.bio: Literary agent and former editor at Pantheon and Vintage. She founded Betsy Amster Literary Enterprises in 1992 and has been called 'a dogged prospector of literary talent' by the Los Angeles Times. A frequent panelist at the LA Times Festival of Books and instructor at UCLA Extension's Writers' Program.

photo.notes: Photo available on LA Times Festival of Books speaker page; also on Publishers Marketplace profile

writers.name: Brenda Hillman
writers.bio: Award-winning poet and Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets. Her collection Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire won the 2014 Griffin Poetry Prize. She is the Olivia Filippi Professor of Poetry at Saint Mary's College of California and is married to fellow poet Robert Hass.
notableWorks: Seasonal Works with Letters on Fire
Extra Hidden Life, Among the Days
In a Few Minutes Before Later

photo.notes: Photo by Robert Hass available on Blue Flower Arts speaker page; also on Poetry Foundation, Academy of American Poets

writers.name: Catherine Barnett
writers.bio: Poet and educator whose collection The Game of Boxes won the James Laughlin Award. She is a recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and a 2022 Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She teaches at NYU and serves as Distinguished Lecturer at Hunter College.
notableWorks: Solutions for the Problem of Bodies in Space
Into Perfect Spheres Such Holes Are Pierced
awards: American Academy of Arts and Letters Award in Literature

photo.notes: Photo by Jacqueline Mia Foster on Academy of American Poets, Poetry Foundation, and official website

writers.name: Catherine Ellis
writers.bio: Writer and oral historian. Co-editor with Sydney Lewis of Say It Plain: A Century of Great African American Speeches, preserving and publishing works from Studs Terkel's interview archive.
notableWorks: Say It Plain: A Century of Great African American Speeches
Say It Loud: Great Speeches on Civil Rights and African American Identity

photo.notes: Limited online presence. Photo may be available through The New Press publisher page. Requires further verification.

writers.name: Charif Shanahan
writers.bio: Poet and translator whose collection Trace Evidence was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, longlisted for the National Book Award, and won the Lambda Literary Award for Gay Poetry. He is an assistant professor at Northwestern University.
notableWorks: Into Each Room We Enter without Knowing
awards: Lambda Literary Award for Gay Poetry
National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship

photo.notes: Photo by Rachel Eliza Griffiths on Northwestern faculty page; also credited to Beowulf Sheehan on some pages

writers.name: Charles Baxter
writers.bio: Novelist and short story writer whose The Feast of Love was a National Book Award finalist. He was the Edelstein-Keller Professor in Creative Writing at the University of Minnesota and has won the Rea Award and PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story.
notableWorks: There's Something I Want You to Do
Burning Down the House: Essays on Fiction
awards: American Academy of Arts and Letters Award

photo.notes: Photo on University of Minnesota English department page; additional photo by Aaron Lavinsky in Minneapolis Sculpture Garden for Star Tribune

writers.name: Christine Deavel
writers.bio: Poet and playwright whose collection Woodnote won the Washington State Book Award and the Dorothy Brunsman Poetry Prize. She co-founded and ran Open Books, Seattle's poetry-only bookstore, with her husband J.W. Marshall from 1995 to 2016.

photo.attribution: Artist Trust / Photo courtesy of the artist
photo.notes: Photo on Artist Trust page; also may have photos from KUOW interview and Seattle Arts & Lectures

writers.name: Claire Vaye Watkins
writers.bio: Author whose debut story collection Battleborn won The Story Prize and Dylan Thomas Prize. Her novel Gold Fame Citrus explores the California drought. A National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 honoree and Guggenheim Fellow, she is a professor at UC Irvine.
notableWorks: I Love You but I've Chosen Darkness
awards: NY Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award

photo.notes: Photo by Lise Watkins on Community of Writers bio page; also on Penguin Random House and Lannan Foundation pages

writers.name: Consuelo Wise
writers.bio: Guatemalan-American poet and Lewis & Clark alumna (BA '09). Her debut hybrid collection boy is a book-length poem confronting grief over the loss of her two brothers. She is a visiting scholar at Portland State University.

photo.notes: Photo on Lewis & Clark Visiting Writers Series event page; also on New Orleans Poetry Festival and Portland State faculty pages

writers.name: Corey Van Landingham
writers.bio: Poet and Lewis & Clark alumna from Ashland, Oregon. Her collection Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens won the Levis Reading Prize. She is a recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, NEA Fellowship, and Wallace Stegner Fellowship, and teaches at the University of Illinois.
notableWorks: Love Letter to Who Owns the Heavens
awards: Ohio State University Press/The Journal Charles B. Wheeler Prize

photo.notes: Photo by Anna Longworth on official website; also on Poetry Foundation, NEA, and University of Illinois pages
